occurrences.line_text: Loe I defie thee, and here challenge make,
Full loth am I (quoth he) as now at earst,
Ne would I gladly combate with mine host,
Vnlesse that I were thereunto enforst.
Sith then ye needs will know the griefe I hoord,
I am th'vnfortunate Matilde by name,
For which I thus doe mourne, and poure forth ceaselesse teares.
Which though I be not wise enough to frame,
Yet as I well it meane, vouchsafe it without blame.
To whom she thus; I am, as now ye see,
I was erewhile, the loue of Calepine:
Since I him lately lost, vneath is to define.
In saluage forrest I him lost of late,
Where I had surely long ere this bene dead,
And I likewise in vaine doe salues to you applie.
The best (sayd he) that I can you aduize,
I must a while forbeare to you to tell;
Till that, as comes by course, I doe recite,
Vile cowheard dogge, now doe I much repent,
That euer I this life vnto thee lent,
To erect this wicked custome, which I heare,
I giuen haue, liue in reproch and scorne;
But onely breath sith that I did forgiue.
Or learn'd the art to please, I doe not fynd.
This well I wote, that she so well applyde
The coward Turpine, whereof now I treat;
What meaneth this, which here I see before?
That euer I for meed did vndertake
The which I earst aduentur'd for your sake.
My due reward, the which right well I deeme
I yearned haue, that life so dearely did redeeme.
Where is the bootie, which therefore I bought,
That recreant knight, whose hated life I sought?
The which discourse as now I must delay,
Till Mirabellaes fortunes I doe further say.
I will them soone acquite, and both of blame assoile.
I was belou'd of many a gentle Knight,
To loue my selfe I learned had in schoole.
Thus I triumphed long in louers paine,
Which I to others did inflict afore,
Disdaine and Scorne, I through the world should stray,
Till I haue sau'd so many, as I earst did slay.
Till I haue sau'd so many, as I earst did slay.
I put the teares of my contrition,
Till to the brim I haue it full defrayd:
And in this bag which I behinde me don,
I put repentaunce for things past and gon.
That all which I put in, fals out anon;
Who mocketh all my paine, & laughs the more I mourn.
And sure I weene, had not the Ladies cry
Vnto your selfe I freely leaue to chose,
Whether I shall you leaue, or from these villaines lose.
But that I needes must by all meanes fulfill
Backe to the furrow which I lately left;
I lately left a furrow, one or twayne
As I it past, that were too great a shame,
And toyle endured, sith I left him last
Sewing the Blatant beast, which I forbore
That certes I your happinesse enuie,
That hauing small, yet doe I not complaine
But doe my self, with that I haue, content;
No better doe I weare, no better doe I feed.
No better doe I weare, no better doe I feed.
Therefore I doe not any one enuy,
The litle that I haue, growes dayly more
What haue I, but to praise th'Almighty, that doth send it?
To them, that list, the worlds gay showes I leaue,
But all the night in siluer sleepe I spend,
And all the day, to what I list, I doe attend.
And all the day, to what I list, I doe attend.
Sometimes I hunt the Fox, the vowed foe
Sometime the fawne I practise from the Doe,
Another while I baytes and nets display,
And when I wearie am, I downe doe lay
And when I wearie am, I downe doe lay
That I disdain'd amongst mine equall peares
For further fortune then I would inquire.
And leauing home, to roiall court I sought;
Where I did sell my selfe for yearely hire,
There I beheld such vainenesse, as I neuer thought.
There I beheld such vainenesse, as I neuer thought.
After I had ten yeares my selfe excluded
I gan my follies to my selfe to plaine,
I from thenceforth haue learn'd to loue more deare
This lowly quiet life, which I inherite here.
He thus replyde; Now surely syre, I find,
That euen I which daily doe behold
The glorie of the great, mongst whom I won,
I shal resolue, or backe to turne againe,
I may here with your selfe some small repose obtaine.
Besides for recompence hereof, I shall
The which as commeth now, by course I will declare.
But why when I them saw, fled they away from me?
Not I so happy, answerd then that swaine,
Right sory I, (saide then Sir Calidore,)
That to thy blisse I made this luckelesse breach,
Who rashly sought that, which I mote not see.
That euer I did liue, this day to see,
Before I saw faire Pastorella dye.
He thus began: Where shall I then commence
Whose heauy tydings now I haue to tell.
I onely scapt through great confusione
Which with those gentle shepherds here I wont to lead.
But now I come into my course againe,
But first, ere I doe his aduentures tell,
For on her brest I with these eyes did vew
And art thou yet aliue, whom dead I long did faine.
All in a woodmans iacket he was clad
But in a Iacket quilted richly rare,
And in his hand a Iacobs staffe, to stay
Snatcht first the one, and then the other Iade,
His tyreling iade he fiercely forth did push,
Vpon a mangy iade vnmeetely set,
Her tyreling iade, was bent her to abuse;
And vnderneath his breech was all to torne and iagged.
Because I could not giue her many a Iane.
Therein resembling Ianus auncient,
And yet his peace is but continuall iarre:
Then fowle reuenging rage, and base contentious iarre.
Acrates sonne of Phlegeton and Iarre;
Outrageous anger, and woe-working iarre,
Troubled with terrour and vnquiet iarre,
Who making vantage of their ciuill iarre,
Till vniuersall peace compound all ciuill iarre.
Tumultuous trouble and contentious iarre,
Ne priuate iarre, ne spite of enemis
Ne euer shewed signe of rancour or of iarre.
Of Iason and Medï¿½ fÂ¦a was ywrit;
All pau'd beneath with Iaspar shining bright,
With that she swaruing backe, her Iauelin bright
For euer when the Squire his iauelin shooke,
And that more wondrous was, in either iaw
Nor harder was from Cerberus greedie iaw
Taking aduantage of his open iaw,
With gaping iawes full greedy at him came,
Themselues, for feare into his iawes to fall,
Were shronke into his iawes, as he did neuer dine.
Does tremble: for his deepe deuouring iawes
For whiles they fly that Gulfes deuouring iawes,
With greedy iawes her readie for to teare;
That round about her iawes one might descry
Betwixt his bloodie iawes, besprinckled all with gore.
That fomed all about his bloody iawes.
Decked with diuerse plumes, like painted Iayes,
Or Ida, where the Gods lou'd to repaire,
Whiles yet on Ida he a shepheard hight,
He snatcht from Ida hill, and with him bare:
Both staring fierce, and holding idely
Where they in idle pompe, or wanton play,
His siluer shield, now idle maisterlesse;
The idle stroke, enforcing furious way,
That idle name of loue, and louers life,
How may a man (said he) with idle speach
But th'idle stroke yet backe recoyld in vaine,
The sight with idle feare did them dismay,
What meane these bloudy vowes, and idle threats,
With idle force did faine them to withstand,
Of some th'aboundance of an idle braine
One sitting idle on a sunny bancke,
His idle humour with fine flattery,
Ne can the man, that moulds in idle cell,
It's eath his idle furie to asswage,
And though he scornd his idle vanitie,
And idle pleasures in his[her] Bowre of Blisse,
And now he has pourd out his idle mind
The Idle lake, my wandring ship I row,
That he awoke out of his idle dreme,
But bent his hastie course towards the idle flood.
Whiles thus they strugled in that idle waue,
And idle offers of thy golden fee;
That all thine idle offers I refuse.
So lost his labour vaine and idle industry.
Foreby that idle strond, of him were told,
And suffred rash Pyrrochles wast his idle might.
Hewing and slashing at their idle shades;
That neuer idle was, ne once could rest a whit.
Such as in idle fantasies doe flit:
All those were idle thoughts and fantasies,
Vaine feasts, and idle superfluity:
But to the ground the idle quarrell fell:
And th'idle breath all vtterly exprest:
Did ferry him ouer the Idle lake:
But he his idle curtesie defide,
His warlike armes, the idle instruments
But wishing it far off, his idle wish doth lose.
And said, Sir knight, these idle termes forbeare,
These idle words (said she) doe nought asswage
Was of himselfe the idle Paramoure;
And that old Dame said many an idle verse,
No idle charmes so lightly may remoue,
And thousand fancies bet his idle braine
The baser wit, whose idle thoughts alway
Ne lend we leisure to his idle toy:
And from Prince Arthur fled with wings of idle feare.
And tell the idle tidings to his Dame:
For which to God he made so many an idle boone.
Her to disport, and idle time to pas,
And in her lap did shed her idle draught,
Troy, that art now nought, but an idle name,
That in the idle aire he mou'd still here and there.
Neither of idle shewes, nor of false charmes aghast.
Stood still amaz'd, holding his idle sweard;
And in their hands their idle troncheons held,
Hath troubled both your mindes with idle thought,
And fild his ballaunce full of idle toys:
With many idle stoups her troubling still:
With idle hopes, which them doe entertaine,
Was sluggish Idlenesse the nourse of sin;
Such one was Idlenesse, first of this company.
Ne suffereth it vncomely idlenesse,
But stretched forth in idlenesse alwayes,
Some plaid with strawes, some idly sat at ease;
Ne day nor night did euer idly rest;
And oft committed fowle Idolatree.
And made her th'Image of Idolatryes;
As th'Idole of her makers great magnificence.
To walke the woods with that his Idole faire,
So hard, this Idole was to be ared,
And setting vp an Idole of his owne,
To God, to doe vnto his Idole most vntrew.
On which that cursed Idole farre proclamed,
There stands an Idole of great note and name,
Consume his hart, and scorch his Idoles face,
All other Idoles, which the heathen adore
I spyde, where at the Idoles feet apart
Thence forth vnto the Idoll they her brought,
To which the Idoll as it were inclining,
And vnderneath this Idoll there doth lie
There he that Idoll saw of massy gold
And eke that Idoll deem'd so costly dere;
Vnder the Idols feete in fearelesse bowre,
And Idols serues; so let his Idols serue the Elfe.
And Idols serues; so let his Idols serue the Elfe.
And to his Idols sacrifice their blood,
Vnder that cursed Idols altar stone;
For which th'IdÃ¦an Ladies disagreed,
Like as Cupido on IdÃ¦an hill,
Through iealous passion weeping inly wroth,
Scarse so conceiued in her iealous thought,
And secretly afflict with iealous feare,
Did closely harbour such a iealous guest)
Iealous suspect as true vntruely drad,
To him, the Shepheard streight with iealousie did frize.
Of thy great grace, and my great ieopardee,
To tell from whence he came through ieopardie,
Hard is his hap, that first fals in his ieopardie.
That shortly he forgot the ieopardie,
Or buried in the ground from ieopardie,
Whilest I through paines and perlous ieopardie,
And a whirlepoole of hidden ieopardy,
In such distresse and doubtfull ieopardy,
And carried her beyond all ieopardy,
Yet seeing nigh him ieopardy extreme,
Which they had past with mickle ieopardy,
Ne stayes, till safe himselfe he see from ieopardy.
But Talus vsde in times of ieopardy
That all the Temple put in ieopardy
The which was certes in great ieopardy,
Ne skilfull of the vncouth ieopardy;
Vppon that Carle, to saue his friend from ieopardy.
Or bide the chaunce at thine owne ieoperdie.
From bels and iesses, which did let her flight,
Therewith she laught, and did her earnest end in iest.
But Cambell thus did shut vp all in iest,
He lowdly gan to laugh, and thus to iest;
All gan to iest and gibe full merilie
Was tickled with delight, and iesting sayd;
Enwrapped in fowle smoke and clouds more blacke then Iet.
Then Iet or Marble far from Ireland brought;
In a rich Iewell, and therein entrayld
Amongst the rest a iewell rich he found,
Adornd with gold and iewels shining cleare,
Her selfe, adorn'd with gems and iewels manifold.
In roiall robes, and many Iewels dight,
And first they spoile her of her iewels deare,
And wicked doome, to Iewes despiteous
So whylome learnd that mighty Iewish swaine,
And after asked him, if he did know
But if of daunger which hereby doth dwell,
To do none ill, if please ye not do well.
For danger great, if not assur'd decay
I saw before mine eyes, if I were knowne to stray.
To seeke her strayed Champion, if she might attaine.
To weet, if dwelling place were nigh at hand;
As if her life vpon the wager lay,
If that of such a Ladie she could tellen ought.
Or if that any else did Ioue excell:
Or if ought higher were then that, did it desyre.
If from their loyall loues he might then moue;
And if that either to that shield had right,
If old Aveugles sonnes so euill heare?
If either salues, or oyles, or herbes, or charmes
For doubtlesse death ensewd, if any him descryde.
If Bacchus merry fruit they did inuent,
Then Vna gan to aske, if ought he knew,
If death it be, it is not the first wound,
If lesse, then that I feare, more fauour I haue found.
To Faerie lond, where yet it may be seene, if sought.
If then it find not helpe, and breedes despaire.
But if thou be, as thou art pourtrahed
With all his powre, to weet, if liuing wight
As if his feare still followed him behind;
What if some litle paine the passage haue,
If in true ballance thou wilt weigh thy state:
If any strength we haue, it is to ill,
And if that no spare cloths to giue he had,
If not well ended at our dying day.
As if in Adamant rocke it had bene pight.
And looked all about, if she might spy
No wonder if he wondred at the sight,
As if late fight had nought him damnifyde,
And looked forth, to weet, if true indeede
And shall find friends, if need requireth soe,
But if your selfe, Sir knight, ye faultie find,
Whom if ye please for to discouer plaine,
What if within the Moones faire shining spheare?
What if in euery other starre vnseene
Of Faerie lond yet if he more inquire,
And if by lookes one may the mind aread,
For if he liue, that hath you doen despight,
As if her hart with sorrow had transfixed beene.
His threatned speare, as if some new mishap
But if that carelesse heauens (quoth she) despise
Her feeble pulse, to proue if any drop
And to her said; Yet if the stony cold
Faire Sir, if euer there ye trauell, shonne
If I or thou dew vengeance doe forbeare,
As if their liues had in his hand beene gaged;
If where those knights for feare of dew vengeaunce
If thou didst, tell me, that I may her ouertake.
But if she had her least helpe to thee lent,
He boldly spake, Sir knight, if knight thou bee,
Ne thou for better hope, if thou his presence stay.
If wonted force and fortune do not much me faile.
As if it had by Natures cunning hand,
To battell, if thou meane her loue to gaine:
If euer loue of Ladie did empierce
But if for me ye fight, or me will serue,
He ran on foot, as if in lucklesse warre
What art thou man, (if man at all thou art)
Wherefore if me thou deigne to serue and sew,
Or if to thy great mind, or greedy vew
If then thee list my offred grace to vse,
If thee list not, leaue haue thou to refuse:
If euer couetous hand, or lustfull eye,
If euer he transgrest the fatall Stygian lawes.
Now therefore, if thou wilt enriched bee,
As if that highest God defie he would;
Thy spouse I will her make, if that thou lust,
But if that thou be such, as I thee see,
To which if he inclined had at all,
If not, leaue vnto me thy knights last patronage.
The guilt, which if he liued had thus long,
Yet if thou wilt renounce thy miscreaunce,
Faire Sir (said he) if in that picture dead
What mote ye weene, if the trew liuely-head
But if the beautie of her mind ye knew,
If that your liues ye loue, as meete ye should;
We would and would againe, if that we could;
As if some pensiue thought co[n]straind her gentle spright.
If it be I, of pardon I you pray;
But if ought else that I mote not deuise,
I will, if please you it discure, assay,
Ne wonder then, if that he were depriu'd
But if some relish of that heauenly lay
As if the rest some wicked hand did rend,
Ne wonder, if these did the knight appall;
Faire Sir, be not displeasd, if disobayd:
As if that hungers point, or Venus sting
As if it had to him bene sacrifide;
Or Eden selfe, if ought with Eden mote compaire.
Wherewith she sighed soft, as if his case she rewd.
But rather shewd more white, if more might bee:
But Palmer, if it mote thee so aggrate,
If pourtrayd it might be by any liuing art.
But if in liuing colours, and right hew,
If ought amis her liking may abuse:
As if that age bad him that burden spare,
To weet if they would turne backe to that place:
But if he haue a Ladie or a Loue,
Therefore a read Sir, if thou haue a loue.
Which in that cloth was wrought, as if it liuely grew.
That but if she did lend her short reliefe,
She softly felt, if any member mooued,
If any puffe of breath, or signe of sence she fand.
As if she had a feuer fit, did quake,
For thy great wonder were it, if such shame
Ah, but if reason faire might you perswade,
If chaunce I him encounter parauaunt;
And if that any drop of slombring rest
But if that loue it be, as sure I read
My crime, (if crime it be) I will it reed.
But if thou may with reason yet represse
But if the passion mayster thy fraile might,
In her warme bed to sleepe, if that she might;
And if thou euer happen that same way
As if ought in this world in secret store
But this I read, that but if remedee
And to him said, If any leaches skill,
And if he then with victorie can lin,
If ay more goodly creature thou didst see;
Th'vsurped crowne, as if that he were wood,
If they be dead, then woe is me therefore:
But if they sleepe, ï¿½ let them soone awake:
But if the heauens did his dayes enuie,
Then of wilde beastes if she had chased beene:
Her now I seeke, and if ye vnderstand
And honour of trew Ladies, if ye may
Meekely she bowed downe, to weete if life
Which if thou gaine, I shalbe well apayd.
But if to loue disloyalty it bee,
If she will not, dye meekly for her sake;
And tell me, if that ye my sonne haue heard,
But if I catch him in this company,
If any tract of him or tydings they mote trace.
Euer alike, as if her former dred
Her counsell, if he should her trust in me repose.
Or fairer then her selfe, if ought algate
Dy, if thou it gainesay: I will away her beare.
But if thee list to see thy Courser ronne,
But if that thou, Sir Satyran, didst weete,
But if Sir Calidore could it presage,
As if he were on some aduenture bent,
Her certaine losse, if not her sure decay:
Which if ye please, to yonder castle turne your gate.
What wonder then, if one of women all did mis?
Then listen Lordings, if ye list to weet
Then if all fayle, we will by force it win,
As if he did a dogge to kenell rate,
Stood gazing, as if suddein great affright
But if it should not grieue you, backe agayne
Indeed he said (if I remember right,)
But when apart (if euer her apart)
Saying, but if she Mercie would him giue
What wonder then, if she were likewise carried?
As if they lay in wait, or else themselues did hide.
As if he could haue kild him with his looke,
And tell thy griefe, if any hidden lye;
Are bound for to reuenge, and punish if they may.
As if the word so spoken, were halfe donne,
As if he heauen and hell would ouerronne,
As if no trespasse euer had bene donne:
As if the wind him on his winges had borne,
This all as bad as she, and worse, if worse ought were.
As if he had bene slombring in the shade,
Him grone, as if his hart were peeces made,
If goodnesse find no grace, nor righteousnesse no meed?
If good find grace, and righteousnesse reward,
Or if that heauenly iustice may withstand
As if his dayes were come to their last reach.
Yet if that heauenly grace some good reliefe
Then is your sorrow, certes if not more;
But yet, if please ye listen to my lore,
If she were thine, and thou as now am I?
And an earth-quake, as if it streight would lose
As if in mind he somewhat had to say,
As if no sorrow she ne felt ne drad;
Is death, or if that ought do death exceed,
But if that thou this Dame doe presently
Her sword high ouer him, if ought he did offend.
Yet otherwise much worse, if worse might bee,
As if their soules they would attonce haue rent
Adowne, as if their springes of life were spent;
As if they secret counsels did partake;
As if but one soule in them all did dwell,
As if the conquest his he surely wist.
As if that life to losse they had forelent,
As if that each ment other to deuoure;
As if but then the battell had begonne:
Then suddenly as if their hearts did faile,
As if he naught but peace and pleasure ment,
But if to match that Lady they had sought
And then it shall be tried, if ye will,
If he misdid, he on himselfe did dight,
As if but now the battell wexed warme.
No wonder then, if that to winne the same
To hide his falshood, then if it were trew:
As if he had in prison long bene pent:
And rend a sunder quite, if he thereto list striue.
And if by fortune any litle nap
Or as if one him suddenly did call.
And if to that auenge by you decreed
And if I hap to fayle, you shall recure my right.
As if he thought her soule to disentrayle.
Fell downe to ground, as if the steele had sence,
Sighing and sobbing sore, as if the paine
But if the heauens helpe to redresse her wrong,
And if it chaunst, (as needs it must in fight)
And bad them, if so be they were not bound,
But stood still mute, as if he had beene dum,
As if she would haue made him vnderstand,
If heauen, then none may it redresse or blame,
If wrathfull wight, then fowle rebuke and shame
But if through inward griefe or wilfull scorne
But if few plants preseru'd through heauenly ayd,
Fearing least if she should him freely set,
And oft imbrast, as if that I were hee,
But if that Dwarfe I could with me conuay,
As if that by one patterne seene somewhere,
As if that euery dint the ghost would riue
